title: 115_s2052
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Care Market Certainty and Mandate Relief Act". It includes provisions for cost-sharing reduction payments. The Health Care Market Certainty and Mandate Relief Act appropriates funds for cost-sharing reductions authorized by Public Law 111-148 for plan years 2017, 2018, and 2019. Adjustments to prior obligations can be made until December 31, 2020. The Health Care Market Certainty and Mandate Relief Act appropriates funds for cost-sharing reductions authorized by Public Law 111-148 for plan years 2017, 2018, and 2019. The Act specifies that payments shall not include coverage of abortion except in cases necessary to save the life of the mother, or in cases of rape or incest. Additionally, a special rule for plan year 2018 payments is outlined, allowing adjustments to prior obligations until December 31, 2020. The Secretary may make payments to a qualified health plan issuer for plan year 2018 if certain conditions are met, including certification from the issuer and State regulators regarding premium rates assumptions. Recovery of past payments is also addressed in the context of the Health Care Market Certainty and Mandate Relief Act. The Secretary may reduce payments to a qualified health plan issuer for a subsequent plan year if it is determined that the issuer increased premium rates for plan year 2018 due to not receiving expected payments or not reducing rates as required. This is in accordance with the Health Care Market Certainty and Mandate Relief Act. The Secretary may make payments to an issuer of a qualified health plan for plan year 2018, even if not eligible under certain conditions in states with a premium adjustment process. Issuers of qualified health plans in a State must reduce premium rates for plan year 2018 to account for assumed payments for cost-sharing reductions. The State must provide information to verify the rate reduction. The reduction of premium rates for qualified health plans must satisfy the reduction requirement, and issuers participating in the process can choose to participate. The Secretaries of Treasury and Health and Human Services will adjust methodologies to correct any overpayments or underpayments. The Secretaries of Treasury and Health and Human Services will adjust methodologies to correct any overpayments or underpayments made by issuers. The text chunk discusses a moratorium on the individual mandate and employer mandate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, suspending their application for specific time periods. Additionally, it mentions an increase in the maximum contribution limit to Health Savings Accounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the limitation on Health Savings Account contributions for certain months between 2017 and 2023. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2017.
